content: let's get miniature we made a miniature world
wow your friend no more where's that super armored
killing machine again hey rodrick great to see you man oh
well yeah you're just a piece of plastic i know i know
it's cool it's cool it's cool hey great to have you with me today on the
dm's craft this is a special episode that combines
two of my favorite things crafting terrain
and crafting stories crafting adventures all right so we're going to combine the
two in this episode and i'm going to show you this
really cool vehicle i made for this fantasy vehicle i made for
my quest givers adventure called on the run so this
monstrous machine mechanical magical monstrous machine
uh is chasing you down this mountain right and uh
it is you know terrifying there's there's hags on it there's
these things called drex which are like these little goblin-like creatures
inside like a hamsters powering this thing and this thing is
frightening right as the hags are chucking magic at you and this big wheel
is is about to squish you so this is a
super fun adventure and a cool craft i really wanted to make something
spectacular for this craft so let's go to my table and i'll show
you how cool this came out you know how you'll see something and
suddenly you'll just get inspiration for a craft well that's what
happened to me with this death wheel i wanted to make the wheel
interesting and unusual and i saw these rolls of
tape at the dollar tree so they were only a dollar each and i thought oh
i could do this interesting and kind of layered idea you can see on the picture
here where the smaller wider roll is in the
center and the larger shorter width rolls are
on the outside so i thought that'd be a really
interesting design and that's what the site i decided to go with
i had the wheels but i needed some texture so what i did is i took
some styrofoam from a clam shell and i cut it up into strips
that i could use to cover the wheels and give them a nice texture
so first i segmented the bits into different planks that would be on the
wheel and then i took this embossing tool and
just pushed into it to get the wooden texture
and this is a really nice cheap way that you can do that
i wanted to add some metal banding to the wheels to make it look like it would
hold the wheel together so what i use is this glossy cardstock
and this is just from a donut box uh what i like about
the glossy part is that the paint doesn't soak into it
and it looks more like a piece of metal as opposed to like a piece of cardstock
with a rough surface that smooth surface gives it a nice look it looks like metal
you'll notice here also that i'm dragging my blade along it
that'll give a little bit of damage and scuff marks to it
and that i've segmented it into squares and the reason i did that was because
i'm going to put spikes on this and i want to
an easy way to measure where the spikes will go when i glue them on
once you get your styrofoam all textured you just cut them out
and hot glue them to the tape rolls i just glued the cardstock banding in
the middle of the wheel and i was good to go
used hot glue on that i had my wood texture and banding on the
wheels but i still had a problem because the outside of the wheels didn't have
any texture and it was still a roll of tape so i had
to figure out how i would fix that and i used my modeling paste i love this
stuff it's great you can find in my links below
in my amazon store so i just painted the thin coat of this on here
on the edge of the wheel or on the edge of the tape roll
and i just dragged a toothpick through it uh towards the center to give it like
a wood like texture and that really worked out fantastic this stuff
is great it dries uh hard but flexible and it's just great
for all kinds of projects like this kind of the lore of the death wheel is that
there are these creatures called drex that are running inside like hamsters
and the drex are kind of these goblin-like creatures so they're being
controlled by their masters and they're running in there like hamsters
and so i imagine that they're kind of in the center that large area of the wheel
and i just had to assemble these so i just uh hot glued them all together
and you can see we got a really interesting look with the two outer
larger parts and the much wider inner part you know of course
with crafting you can do everything by hand but sometimes it's just easier just
to use a prefab product especially if it's not very expensive
and i decided to use these as the caps for the wheel so now i wouldn't have to
cut out perfect circles to fit and they already had the wood texture on them so
that was perfect i want to have a four castle which is
kind of the command deck of the wheel and uh magic users sit on there control
the wheel with magic and you know blast enemies and that kind
of thing you can also have plenty of room for other troops
so i made the height of the wall a little taller than you might expect for
a miniature because the miniatures are going to hide behind it
and i've got to have kind of a window accreditation in the front
where the driver can look out right so that was kind of the idea with this
so i made that uh an inch and a half tall and then i made the base
uh three inches by four inches so i just cut that out of thick card stock that
you can find at my amazon store once i cut that out i just measured my
clam shell pieces out did the same thing drew lines through it
uh used the embossing tool and got the wood
texture on it and then just cut pieces out that would
cover up the cardstock and give it a nice texture
nice wooden texture i got the forecast all glued together
with my hot glue gun and i didn't put texture on the inside
yet i used that to last so that i could just put it on there and
then measure uh you know with the differential from the bottom you know
already in it that way i didn't have to measure that out pre-measure that out i
could just measure it out after and uh then just
glue it in there and it's all set all good to go i use those prefab wooden
discs before now i'm going to use these doll
stands these wooden doll stands and they've already got the wood texture
on them so it's perfect so i'm going to glue one on the wheel
and then one on the four castle and that's going to make it so that i can
link the two together i decided to add another detail i love
these gears that you can get you can get them in bulk i have a link
below in my amazon store but you can get them in bulk just about
any craft place and these are great to add to projects
particularly if there's some kind of pseudo-mechanical thing like this is
so i decided to add some detail with these
cogs onto the places where the two wheels will connect
i took a delve into my wooden bits box and i found these
interesting shapes that i'm going to use on the four castle to give it some
detail i added the strut out of my bit box and
say it with me what did i use e6000 that's right
it's great for gluing various materials together like wood and metal
so it'll be perfect for this application okay
i want to warn you about a big no-no do not use the e6000
on the foam or it will melt it okay i used my glue gun on this and i glued the
wooden bits to the forecastle but i also used some of the
wooden bits to cover up the edges where the foam meets the cardstock and
you can use that to cover that up and it looks great
i glued some plastic spikes on on wow that really transforms the piece
i did glue these on with e6000 because you'll notice that
none of the pieces are touching the styrofoam they're all touching
something else so it's okay to use the e6000 which works great on plastic and
other materials beads can be used for great detail and i
glued some to the corners as well as the center of the wall on each side
then on top of each bead i glued a plastic spike so this thing is going to
even be more wicked looking so really cool way
to get this painted it's going to look
great i wanted to add some more detail to the center of the wheel so i
had these teardrop shapes i just white glue those on the wood
and i decided to add more uh a bigger struts
to the center so i just glued some same the same pieces as the first one
to each other with the white glue and i got like a wider looking strut like a
compound strut i also added some cogs to the outside of
the struts to make it look like it's it's going
through the strut like it's bolted into the strut a strip of donut box white
glued to the center of the struts like a banding bar and then i added some
rhinestones for the bolts that were holding it on
i want to add one last little detail to the forecastle so i cut a skull in half
with this blade be careful when you do this kind of stuff
then i e6000 to a piece of wood i had that looked like a shield i thought that
was really neat and then i glued that to the top of the
forecast along the other wood pieces so a really cool look i think that really
topped it off my last little detail was a cosmetic
thing i used some modeling paste around the window in the front to uh
blend the layers together of the cardstock and
the foam so you don't see the separate layers it just like just looks like one
piece i want to spray paint it for the most
part but you really can't because the foam would melt
so that's a big problem so to strengthen and color in the foam
i used black gesso mixed with mod podge matte mod podge and i painted all the
foam areas with it so not only does it strengthen
it it actually protects it from the spray paint
it was actually a pretty simple matter to paint the thing i just painted
all the wooden areas with the dark brown and all the metal
and banded areas with a gunmetal once the base coat was dry i just gave
it a once over my black wash and that is just water black gesso i
really like the black pigment of the gesso uh it has
floor wax glossy floor wax and a few drops of dish soap and that
makes a really great wash that goes in all the cracks and crevices
to finish up the paint job i used to use a mushroom brown which is kind of this
muted brown and it looks great it makes it look like old wood
i discovered that the color shifting black from plaid
is really great for distressing you can see on the metal banding here
that i added something on there and really makes a great
look for distressing and discolorations variation of color can
give your piece some interest so i use this tan
as another dry brush and i use this scruffy brush it's a nice application
because it kind of breaks up the color onto the piece and it looks like worn
wood i really like that effect this is a little bright right now as i'm
putting on but it will darken up as it dries
so take that into consideration when you paint
one thing you'll notice on the bottom here is i didn't have the spikes go all
the way around that way the wheel can stand up on its
own without having any kind of stand you
know to stand on uh if i put the spikes on it would be
sticking up off the table so i decided not to put the spikes on
the whole way around now let's take a look at the completed
piece with the troops in the back so you can see how it looks all together and
ready for the table top
do if you'd like to play the adventure
featuring this death wheel check out questgivers.com
the module name is on the run but the module's also featured in the 12-part
campaign that's called the north road campaign
12 adventures four short quests and an epic campaign that is ready to go right
to your table it is system neutral so you can use it
in any system you like that's what i really love about it
and i'm really proud of these adventures and i think you're going to have fun
running them so check out questgivers.com to pick that up
i would like to give a round of applause for these
people for helping to bring you the dm's craft
thank you very much for your generous
support
that's a lot of names thank you so much
you
